results.title: Thain's CIT buys OneWest for $3.4bn
results.content:
The banker who sold Merrill Lynch to Bank of America is making an acquisition.

CIT, a US lender run by Merrill's former chief executive John Thain, has agreed to buy OneWest Bank for $3.4bn.

Mr Thain, who has led CIT since 2009, has been looking for acquisitions and last month agreed to buy Direct Capital, a lender based in New Hampshire.

OneWest is a bigger deal and pushes CIT into southern California, where OneWest has more than 70 branches and $23bn in assets.

Mr Thain said the acquisition was "transformational" and will

Combine CIT's national middle market lending platform with OneWest's wholesale lending and branch banking franchise.

Under the deal, investors in IMB, the holding company of OneWest, will receive $2bn in cash and 31.3m CIT shares.
results.abstract: The banker who sold Merrill Lynch to Bank of America is making an acquisition.

results.title: Lonmin appoints Beamish as permanent chairman
results.content:
Lonmin, a South African platinum producer plagued by industrial strikes, has appointed Brian Beamish as new chairman with immediate effect.

Anglo American Platinum, Impala and Lonmin, the biggest producers of the precious metal, have been badly hurt by a series of strikes at their South African mines.

Mr Beamish was appointed interim chairman earlier this year, following the retirement of Roger Phillimore, and will now take over permanently. In a statement to the London Stock Exchange he said:

Lonmin holds rights over a suite of exceptional PGM assets, has unmatched technical strengths and good people with the drive and skills to restore the business to profitability. The return to work after a damaging strike of unprecedented length is progressing well. I will continue to work closely with our chief executive officer, Ben Magara, in leading the board and company through the challenges ahead, creating value for shareholders and all stakeholders.
results.abstract: Lonmin, a South African platinum producer plagued by industrial strikes, has appointed Brian Beamish as new chairman with immediate effect.

results.title: Credit Suisse: another mixed bag
results.content:
Credit Suisse's results are invariably a mixed bag – and just as invariably, with their array of "core strategic" and "core non-strategic" results, they are presented as such. What to make of the latest offering?

First, the Swiss investment banking and wealth management group's SFr700m second-quarter loss was not as bad as expected, even after it paid SFr1.6bn (after tax) in May and pleaded guilty to settle a probe into whether it helped US clients to evade taxes.

Now to the bright spots. Its performance in fixed income, commodities and currencies or Ficc trading was better than expected, as revenues rose by about 4 per cent - bucking the Wall Street trend (down 9 per cent on average) - as investors lap up yield products in a classic case of make hay while you can.

Investors need to reflect on the quality – including the sustainability - of that beat, however. As quantitative easing is unwound, the cheap money chasing yield in Europe could soon crumble. Wisely, Credit Suisse is already pulling out of its sub-scale commodities trading activity.

A pity then that Credit Suisse's core equities franchise reported such a dip (more than 18 per cent off last year's admittedly high base) in equity trading revenues in the business being kept, standing out as one of the main drags on underlying earnings.

And costs in the investment banking area are still relatively high – a reminder that Credit Suisse CEO Brady Dougan still has more to do to restructure his bank – though there is clear progress in automation of foreign exchange trading and rationalisation of its rates products.

And while Credit Suisse looks to be on track to hit its end-2015 cost reduction target of over SFr4.5bn, it may need to add more stretch to those targets given the uncertainty in investment banking markets. No cigar yet for the investment bankers, then.

That leaves Credit Suisse's private banking and wealth franchise to support the group – or not, as it turns out.

Although it attracted SFr10bn of net inflows – a level not surpassed since the first quarter of 2013 - revenue in the area that is increasingly being shaped as the group's core (à la UBS) slipped by a worse than expected 9 per cent in the business being kept.

It gets worse: Credit Suisse's closely-watched gross margin fell again – to a worse-than-expected 99 basis points, from 112bp a year ago, partly as assets under management swelled.

And though Credit Suisse's peer-lagging Basel III capital ratio of 9.5 per cent looks on track to beat 10 per cent by year-end, Mr Dougan still needs to shrink leverage in his investment bank. Risk-weighted assets, for example, declined only to SFr279bn from SFr281bn a year earlier. All the more reason to keep up property and non-core asset sales.

The cigar box is still firmly shut.
results.abstract: Credit Suisse's results are invariably a mixed bag – and just as invariably, with their array of "core strategic" and "core non-strategic" results, they are presented as such. What to make of the latest offering?

results.title: Fast New York Open: US inflation in focus
results.content:
Global political tensions have been front and centre for fixed-income markets over the last week, pushing Treasury yields close to their lowest this year.

That focus should shift somewhat on Tuesday with the release of US inflation figures for June. The latest snapshot of consumer prices comes against a backdrop of concern in some quarters over whether the Fed will have to raise interest rates quicker than it expects.

Although June's figures aren't forecast to reveal an acceleration in inflation, they are expected to show another month of headline inflation above 2 per cent and core inflation, which strips out food and energy, at 2 per cent.

Steve Englander, a strategist at Citigroup, says that the majority of investors expect Fed chairwoman Janet Yellen to stick to her signal to keep interest rates low for a long period. As he says, investors are:

Treating the Fed as an outer-orbit risk rather than as an asteroid taking dead aim.

Alongside inflation data at 8:30am New York time, there are new home sales figures for June that are due at 10am.

In late morning trading in London, the yield on the ten-year Treasury was up 2 basis points at 2.49 per cent. Futures suggest the S&P 500 will open little changed.

It's also the busiest day so far for second-quarter earnings, with Apple, Microsoft, Verizon and Coca-Cola among the companies lifting the lid on their second quarter.
results.abstract: Global political tensions have been front and centre for fixed-income markets over the last week, pushing Treasury yields close to their lowest this year.

results.title: UK industrial orders disappoint in July
results.content:
Order books are no longer bulging for UK manufacturers, judging by July industrial trends data, which show much lower than expected growth in orders.

The Confederation of British Industry's (CBI's) industrial trends index for orders has risen by just +2, compared to +11 last month and expectations of +8 from economists polled by Reuters.

The figure is the difference between manufacturers reporting growth and contraction compared to the norm in order books.

Nevertheless, the CBI said its survey of 481 firms showed robust growth in orders in the three months to July, with 41 per cent of businesses reporting an increase in total orders, and 17 per cent a decrease, giving a balance of +24, the highest since April 1995 (+27).

Export orders were flat but companies were upbeat about the next quarter, "with expectations for total new orders growth at their strongest since 1977, and export orders set to rebound".

For the year ahead, manufacturers' plans for investment in product and process innovation were at their strongest since 1989, with robust plans for spending on plant and machinery, the CBI said.

Katja Hall, CBI Deputy Director-General, commented:

The recovery in the manufacturing sector is keeping a good pace. Industry is performing well as orders and hiring are on the up, and investment intentions for the year ahead are looking healthy across the board.

It is not all plain sailing however, and there are still risks to the recovery. These include increasing international political instability, and the recent rise in sterling, which could be weighing on exports. We need to continue to help manufacturers to export their products to high-growth markets across the globe, to give a healthy and sustainable boost to the UK's recovery.

results.title: Kidston sells stake to finance Asian expansion
results.content:
Cath Kidston, the British designer famed for her eponymous chintzy prints and accessories, has sold down some of her personal stake in the brand to finance expansion in Asia, targeting 100 stores in China, reports Claer Barrett.

The deal, which was announced on Tuesday morning in London, will see private equity house Baring Asia acquire a "substantial" stake in the brand from management and its existing majority owner TA Associates, the US private equity investor.

The brand's quintessentially British prints have proved hugely popular with Asian consumers, and the company said its new partnership with Baring would enable a broader expansion into the region.

Dar Chen, a managing director at Baring Asia, told the FT that he envisaged "an excess of 100 stores in China", though he would not be drawn on the pace of the expansion.

Cath Kidston currently has just four stores in mainland China. Earlier this month, the brand opened its 100th overseas store in Seoul, South Korea, bringing its total stores to 166.

The UK is its biggest market, followed by Japan – whose Fast Retailing group, the owner of Uniqlo, was the subject of earlier bid speculation – and then Korea. Its first store in the Philippines will open later this year.

TA Associates previously owned 65 per cent of the company, with Ms Kidston and the management team owning the remainder. Following the deal, TA and Baring will share "equal ownership" with Ms Kidston and the management team retaining a smaller holding.

None of the parties involved would disclose precise details about the price of the transaction, or the final split of the company's ownership.

Last December, when the company first hired UBS to "assess its options", initial reports suggested that a deal could value the whole group at £250m.

At that time, Kenny Wilson, chief executive of Cath Kidston, said he would be "disappointed with that," adding: "We are one of the UK's fastest-growing companies. We are not going to randomly sell for £250m."

Known as the "home of modern vintage", Ms Kidston founded the business in 1993 with a single shop in London's Holland Park. Selling through its own stores and concessions, the brand offers a range of products including home furnishings, handbags, clothing and accessories.
results.abstract: Cath Kidston, the British designer famed for her eponymous chintzy prints and accessories, has sold down some of her personal stake in the brand to finance expansion in Asia, targeting 100 stores in China, reports Claer Barrett.

results.title: UK finances improve slower than recovery
results.content:
The UK's public finances improved slightly in June, but remained worse than expected given the economic recovery.

Economics reporter Emily Cadman reports that the government borrowed £11.4bn in June to cover the gap between spending in revenues, just £0.1bn less than the year before.

The higher than expected figure – city economists had been expecting borrowing of £10.65bn in June – took borrowing in the three months to June to £36.1bn, £2.5bn or 7.3 per cent higher than the previous year.

The Treasury believes that much of the weakness is down to unusual patterns in income tax receipts last year, as wealthier taxpayers moved their income around to take advantage of the announced cut in the top tax rate to 45 per cent.

A spokesperson for the Treasury stressed that the borrowing figures continued to be in line with forecasts predicting the deficit will be halved by the end of the year, adding "but the job is not yet done, which is why we must continue to work through the plan that is building a resilient economy."

Samuel Tombs, senior UK economist at Capital Economics, said the numbers underlined that "fiscal consolidation still has a long way to go yet before the public finances are restored to a sustainable footing".

results.title: Saudi Arabia opening $530bn market is a big deal
results.content:
It was a classic Saudi announcement: years of rumours and inertia, followed by an unheralded, obtuse statement in Arabic on the website of a state body that was so discrete that most media only picked up on its importance the day after it was posted.

But Saudi Arabia planning to open up its $530bn stock market to foreigners is potentially a big deal – for both the country and emerging markets as a whole.

The country's Capital Markets Authority has allowed foreign investors indirect access through "total return swaps" since 2008, but many money managers have been reluctant to use these derivatives, as they only entitle the holders to the economic benefits of share ownership, rather than actual control.

Direct access, through a China-style "qualified foreign financial institutions" system, could be a game-changer. The Saudi Arabian Tadawul has a market capitalisation of $530bn, making it a bigger stock market than Mexico, Indonesia and the Netherlands, in line with Malaysia and South Africa, and bigger than Colombia and Chile combined.

If it is eventually included in stock market indices, it would become an important part of benchmarks. Renaissance Capital's Daniel Salter estimates that it would form almost two-thirds of the MSCI Frontier Markets index, or 4.4 per cent of the MSCI Emerging Markets gauge, about the same as Russia.

Moreover, Saudi Arabia's market is extremely liquid for a recondite, off-piste bourse. Renaissance Capital's Charles Robertson puts the three-month average daily trading volume at $2bn, compared to just $26m for Nigeria last year.

The dominance of retail investors means that it is an exceptionally volatile market, but part of the reason why Saudi Arabia is now opening up is that it hopes more longer-term institutional investment will dampen the Tadawul's wild swings.

Since a brutal crash in 2006 – which bankrupted many Saudis who had ploughed their savings into the bourse, and triggered some social strife – the regulator has sharpened its teeth and clamped down on pump-and-dump schemes, insider trading and other market abuses. The CMA is now one of the more respected regulators in the Gulf.

Adding to the lustre is Saudi Arabia's economic potential. Although oil remains the country's dominant industry and source of revenue, the government is ploughing money into various parts of the economy to diversify its output.

The exact timing remains unclear, and Saudi Arabia has a tendency to move slowly. Local officials indicated an opening up to the FT in 2012, but little happened. But the potential is immense. As Mr Robertson noted:

This is long awaited and is likely to see a surge of foreign inflows into the Saudi market – particularly if/when it joins an MSCI index. It is a rival for money that might otherwise be invested in Russia, which is one reason Rencap is opening up in MENA in 2014. Our MENA team is very excited.
results.abstract:
It was a classic Saudi announcement: years of rumours and inertia, followed by an unheralded, obtuse statement in Arabic on the website of a state body that was so discrete that most media only picked up on its importance the day after it was posted.

But Saudi Arabia planning to open up its $530bn stock market to foreigners is potentially a big deal – for both the country and emerging markets as a whole.

results.title: SSP hires North America CEO from Compass
results.content:
SSP, the food court specialist for travellers, has followed up its London float this month with news of a new boss of its North America business.

The operator of Upper Crust, Starbucks, Caffè Ritazza, Burger King, Millie's Cookie and other outlets said Les Cappetta, currently chief executive of SSP North America, is moving up to the chairman's role and Michael Svagdis is joining the company from Compass Group as the new CEO.

It said:

Since Les joined the business in 2007, SSP North America has enjoyed significant growth and the team has delivered a string of successes, including the recent openings of over 80 restaurants in JFK Terminal 4, Phoenix, San Diego, Sacramento Winnipeg and Houston.

Michael Svagdis joins SSP next month from Compass Group plc where he has been CEO, Eurest Dining Services since 2011. Prior to this, he was president of Morrison Healthcare Services since 2005.

Kate Swann, group CEO, commented:

Michael has an excellent track record and the right balance of skills to lead the well-established SSP North America team through its next exciting phase of development and growth.
results.abstract: SSP, the food court specialist for travellers, has followed up its London float this month with news of a new boss of its North America business.

results.title: Citigroup hires another European dealmaker
results.content:
Citigroup has hired yet another senior dealmaker in continental Europe, as the bank continues to beef up its operations in the region.

Daniel Schäfer in London reports that the US lender has poached Nicolas Desombre from Credit Suisse to become its head of investment banking in France.

Based in Paris, Mr Desombre will also be Citi's global co-head of insurance, in line with the bank's strategy to combine sector and country roles at senior level. He will replace Kevin McLoughlin, who departed for rival Bank of America Merrill Lynch in March this year.

Mr Desombre is one in a series of senior hires the bank has made in the past 18 months, in an effort to enter the top three in European investment banking fee rankings within three years.

Last year, the bank shot from 10th to fifth in the European league tables, a position it held steady in the first half of this year.

At the same time as hiring senior dealmakers, the US lender has also slashed costs at its European investment bank by sharply thinning out the ranks of junior staff.

"I'm delighted with where we are in our strategy to upgrade our talent while trimming costs throughout the investment bank," Manolo Falco, head of Citi's corporate and investment banking in Europe, the Middle East and Africa said.

"We will continue to invest with further selective hires in our industry teams and the UK," he added.

The bank, which was heavily scarred in the financial crisis years, had started its senior hiring spree more than a year ago when it brought in Luigi de Vecchi, also a former Credit Suisse banker, as chairman for corporate and investment banking in continental Europe.

Last month, the bank announced it would bring in another Credit Suisse banker, Anthony Diamandakis, to head its European alternative assets group, which caters to private equity clients.

It also hired Ben Story last year from Deutsche Bank to become the first outsider to head UK investment banking and broking, after the US lender's acquisition of the unit from Schroders 14 years ago.
results.abstract: Citigroup has hired yet another senior dealmaker in continental Europe, as the bank continues to beef up its operations in the region.
